title: 110_s2006
content: The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may provide disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may provide disaster assistance for privately-owned or investor-owned power facilities that provide electric or natural gas service to retail customers under State or local jurisdiction, including leased facilities. Conditions for contributions under the Act are also amended. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may provide disaster assistance for privately-owned or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster for repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement, including associated expenses. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" offers assistance to private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster for repair and associated expenses. The act defines conditions for assistance based on previous major disasters within a 10-year timeframe. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" provides assistance to private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster within a 10-year timeframe. The President may offer contributions for repair, restoration, or replacement of power facilities under specific conditions. The President may provide contributions to private or investor-owned power facilities for repair, restoration, or replacement only if certain conditions are met, including costs exceeding $2,500 per retail customer affected by the disaster. The President may provide contributions to private or investor-owned power facilities for repair, restoration, or replacement if the total costs of the previous disaster exceeded $500,000,000 and 25% or more of the population had taxable income below the Federal poverty level. Private or investor-owned power facilities with taxable income below the Federal poverty level after a major disaster can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of the disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards total costs. Federal assistance must be provided within 30 days of a major disaster declaration or after the owner of a private or investor-owned power facility contributes $10,000,000 towards repair costs. Assistance is limited to eligible costs and expenses. The Federal assistance for a major disaster declaration is limited to eligible costs and expenses exceeding $10,000,000 directly incurred by the owner of a private or investor-owned power facility. The costs of all previous major disasters within a 12-month period are aggregated for determining assistance approval. In the context of Federal assistance for major disaster declarations, the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities in the eligibility for assistance. The President must approve or disapprove assistance applications within 30 days of receipt. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities for assistance. Owners of such facilities may opt for a contribution instead of repairs, with the amount set at 75%. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act allows owners of private or investor-owned power facilities to opt for a contribution instead of repairs, receiving 75% of the Federal estimate cost. The funds can be used for repairing, restoring, or expanding other power facilities owned by the person or constructing new facilities. Funds contributed under this paragraph can be used for repairing, restoring, or expanding private or investor-owned power facilities, constructing new facilities, or funding hazard mitigation measures in the affected area. The amendment allows funds to be used for repairing, restoring, or expanding private or investor-owned power facilities in the affected area. The Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with Section 3 taking effect immediately.
